newsitem.title: UK: Dollar steady above 1.69 marks and shy of 116 yen.
newsitem.headline: Dollar steady above 1.69 marks and shy of 116 yen.

text.p: The dollar stuck to familiar ranges just below 116 yen and above 1.69 marks in early Europe, finding little impetus to break either way, said traders.
"The dollar is lacking a bit of interest, to be honest. We've got a long-weekend coming up and some of the banks are off," said a senior dealer at a UK merchant bank.
At 0720 GMT dollar/mark was trading at 1.6910/15 against 1.6943/53 in late Europe on Thursday, though above overnight lows around 1.6880 marks.
Against the yen, the dollar was unchanged at 115.80/5.90 against 115.80/85 in late Europe on Thursday.

Traders said the dollar was relegated to the side-lines as the market eyed a stumble in sterling, punished by speculation Bank of England Governor Eddie George might not be reappointed at the end of his five-year term next year.
"Most interest is on sterling and its crosses after the well-publicised dispute between (finance minister) Gordon Brown and Eddie George," said the trader.
At 0735 GMT, sterling/mark was trading at 2.7535/45 against 2.7845/55 in late dealings on Thursday.
Dollar markets, however, should find some comfort from the overnight release of the Federal Reserve's March 25 minutes.

Analysts said that as the minutes showed the Fed voting unanimously at its March 25 meeting to raise the federal funds rate by a quarter percentage point, positioning toward higher rates should therefore be a catalyst for the dollar to edge higher in the weeks ahead.

But not all analysts are as optimistic. "We haven't seen a dramatic response from interest-rate markets. Unless the economic data shows the economy is rapidly rebounding from its slight slowdown, there will be doubt in people's minds whether a tightening is inevitable at the next FOMC," said Paul Meggyesi, senior currency economist at Deutsche Morgan Grenfell.
"The report leaves a couple of question marks about the near-term direction of rates," he added.

German April month/month producer prices were a touch higher than expected as they grew 0.3 month/month and 0.9 percent year/year against forecasts for 0.1 percent month/month growth and of 0.7 percent year/year.
"Producer prices were slightly worse than expected. But they do not alter the outlook for Bundesbank policy," Meggyesi said.
